editors_note.headline: This week
editors_note.thesis: This week's signal is clear: business model decisions are moving faster than product roadmaps. If you're not tracking How Ricursive Intelligence raised $335M at a $4B valuation in 4 months, you're already behind.
editors_note.hook: The headline drives the week, but the real question is what it means for your vendor assumptions and Q2 plans.
editors_note.spotlight: The lead story is the most likely to change near-term decisions for teams shipping AI products.
editors_note.underhyped: GT-HarmBench: Benchmarking AI Safety Risks Through the Lens of Game Theory deserves more attention than it's getting.
editors_note.risk: Vendor and pricing risk is elevated this week — review your dependency list.

lead_story.title: How Ricursive Intelligence raised $335M at a $4B valuation in 4 months
lead_story.what_happened: An investment round for Ricursive Intelligence signals growing market interest in the space.
lead_story.our_take: Teams that factor Ricursive Intelligence into next quarter early usually gain execution room later.
lead_story.what_to_do: Flag Ricursive Intelligence for your leadership team — it may shift near-term priorities.

sections.title: Industry Radar
sections.deck: The moves that change product plans, budgets, and positioning.

articles.title: OpenClaw founder Peter Steinberger is joining OpenAI
articles.summary: OpenClaw is a development worth monitoring for near-term product and tooling decisions (via The Verge AI).
articles.what_happened: The OpenClaw development has implications for vendor strategy and competitive positioning.
articles.why_it_matters: The OpenClaw shift affects competitive positioning — factor it into Q2 planning.
articles.what_to_do: Set a reminder to check OpenClaw for downstream changes in 2 weeks.
articles.our_take: Competitive dynamics are shifting — pay attention to who benefits and who gets squeezed.

articles.title: Introducing Lockdown Mode and Elevated Risk labels in ChatGPT
articles.summary: A fresh release of ChatGPT is now available for teams ready to evaluate alternatives (via OpenAI Blog).
articles.what_happened: ChatGPT launched with features aimed at the current gap in existing toolchains.
articles.why_it_matters: If you're shopping for alternatives, ChatGPT belongs on the shortlist.
articles.what_to_do: Add ChatGPT as a discussion item in your next strategy or planning meeting.
articles.our_take: Strategic positioning around ChatGPT is shifting faster than most roadmap cycles account for.

sections.title: Builder's Bench
sections.deck: New tooling worth evaluating in an actual workflow this week.

articles.title: Custom Kernels for All from Codex and Claude
articles.summary: Custom Kernels is a development worth monitoring for near-term product and tooling decisions (via Hugging Face Blog).
articles.what_happened: A new tool release around Custom Kernels targets gaps in current developer workflows.
articles.why_it_matters: Custom Kernels is worth evaluating if your current tools are hitting limits.
articles.what_to_do: Allocate one afternoon to test Custom Kernels against your top use case.
articles.our_take: Tools are only as good as the problem they solve for you. Try it on a real task, not a tutorial.

articles.title: Join us for Interrupt: The Agent Conference
articles.summary: Interrupt is a development worth monitoring for near-term product and tooling decisions (via LangChain Blog).
articles.what_happened: A new tool release around Interrupt targets gaps in current developer workflows.
articles.why_it_matters: This year, wes coming next for agents—and how.
articles.what_to_do: Try Interrupt on a non-critical task this week and log the results.
articles.our_take: Don't adopt tools based on hype. Run it against your ugliest edge case first.

sections.title: Open Source Watch
sections.deck: Repos with momentum that might deserve a deeper look.

articles.title: zeroclaw
articles.summary: Zeroclaw is a development worth monitoring for near-term product and tooling decisions (via GitHub Trending (AI/ML)).
articles.what_happened: Zeroclaw is picking up momentum in the open-source community.
articles.why_it_matters: Momentum behind zeroclaw is real, but maintenance quality should gate adoption decisions.
articles.what_to_do: Review zeroclaw issue tracker, last commit date, and license before considering adoption.
articles.our_take: Star velocity tells you whats popular, not whats reliable. Check the issue backlog before the star count.

sections.title: Ship-It Playbooks
sections.deck: Practical implementation guides you can adapt quickly.
sections.promise: One thing to try this week.

articles.title: Alibaba Qwen Team Releases Qwen3.5-397B MoE Model with 17B Active Parameters and 1M Token Context for AI agents
articles.summary: The Alibaba Qwen Team model release is worth benchmarking against your current baseline (via MarkTechPost).
articles.what_happened: Alibaba Cloud just updated the open-source landscape.
articles.why_it_matters: Strong numbers from Alibaba Qwen Team could reset your baseline — but only if they hold on production data.
articles.what_to_do: Work through the Alibaba Qwen Team tutorial and modify one step for your own use case.
articles.our_take: Tutorials are blueprints, not gospel. Adapt one step to your own constraints and you'll learn more.

articles.title: I Built a Multi-Agent Think Tank for Personal Productivity — Here's the Architecture
articles.summary: Research on Multi introduces methods that could influence applied work if results hold (via Dev.to AI).
articles.what_happened: Three AI agents analyze my life.
articles.why_it_matters: One synthesizes their insights into actionable moves.
articles.what_to_do: Follow the Multi guide, but adapt one step to fit your actual production constraints.
articles.our_take: The value of a tutorial is the first thing you build after reading it, not the reading itself.

sections.title: Lab Notes
sections.deck: Research and model updates with downstream product impact.

articles.title: GT-HarmBench: Benchmarking AI Safety Risks Through the Lens of Game Theory
articles.authors: Pepijn Cobben, Xuanqiang Angelo Huang, Thao Amelia Pham et al.
articles.summary: New performance numbers for HarmBench need independent validation before changing production decisions (via arXiv CS.AI).
articles.what_happened: New performance numbers for HarmBench could change cost-quality tradeoffs if they replicate.
articles.why_it_matters: If HarmBench numbers replicate on real workloads, current model or tool selections may need revisiting.
articles.what_to_do: Compare the HarmBench eval setup to yours — check if the benchmark conditions match your workload.
articles.our_take: Benchmark wins look impressive on paper, but production workloads rarely match evaluation conditions.

learn_this_week.title: Google Machine Learning Crash Course
learn_this_week.note: Interactive exercises with TensorFlow. Google's internal ML training, now public.

prompt_of_the_week.text: Rewrite this API documentation to be developer-friendly. Keep it accurate but make it scannable with clear examples.
prompt_of_the_week.why: Bad docs are the #1 reason developers abandon tools. Asking for 'scannable with clear examples' targets the two things devs actually need: quick answers and copy-pasteable code.
prompt_of_the_week.tip: Paste the existing docs. Specify your audience (junior devs, senior engineers, etc.).
